content: I never took a course on commutative algebra because in grad school I was mainly interested in mathematical physics, so I'm just finally now learning Nakayama's lemma - because I need it for something.

There are many alternative formulations, some perhaps easier to remember than others. MathOverflow someone gave this nice mnemonic for it which happens to match what I actually need:

IM=M  ⟹  im=m I M = M \implies i m = m IM=M⟹im=m

What does this mean? It means:

Nakayama's Lemma. Let III be an ideal in a commutative ring RRR and let MMM be a finitely generated RRR-module. If IM=MIM=MIM=M then there exists i∈Ii \in Ii∈I such that im=mim = mim=m for all m∈Mm \in Mm∈M.
This instantly implies something I wanted to know: if III is an ideal in a commutative ring RRR with I2=II^2 = II2=I, then I=pRI = p RI=pR for some p∈Rp \in Rp∈R with p2=pp^2 = pp2=p.

Starting from this simple formulation I'm finally getting more interested in the many alternative formulations and consequences, some of which sound more conceptual, like

If f:M→Mf: M \to Mf:M→M is a surjective endomorphism of a finitely generated RRR-module, then fff is an isomorphism.

or

Any basis of the fiber of a coherent sheaf at a point extends to a minimal generating set of local sections.

or

A finitely generated module over a local ring is projective only if it is free.

John Baez said:

This instantly implies something I wanted to know: if III is an ideal in a commutative ring RRR with I2=II^2 = II2=I, then I=pRI = p RI=pR for some p∈Rp \in Rp∈R with p2=pp^2 = pp2=p.

I don't understand how you get this instantly. And is it even true? I've seen it written on the internet with the additional hypothesis that III is finitely generated.

The ideal does have to be finitely generated to apply Nakayama's Lemma, indeed. But otherwise it's immediate, as:

  • an ideal inherits the structure of a module,
  • therefore there exists p∈Ip \in Ip∈I with pi=ipi = ipi=i for all i∈Ii \in Ii∈I,
  • in particular, p2=pp^2 = pp2=p,
  • pR⊆IpR \subseteq IpR⊆I since p∈Ip \in Ip∈I; I⊆pRI \subseteq pRI⊆pR since pI=IpI = IpI=I.

John Baez said:

Starting from this simple formulation I'm finally getting more interested in the many alternative formulations and consequences, some of which sound more conceptual, like

If f:M→Mf: M \to Mf:M→M is a surjective endomorphism of a finitely generated RRR-module, then fff is an isomorphism.

Yes, this is a good one. Nakayama's lemma seems to be like Yoneda's lemma, being one of these simple results that people in the know use all the time and is coincidentally named after a Japanese mathematician.

I'm not particularly in the know, but over a decade ago I wrote at the nLab, "Nakayama’s lemma is a simple but fundamental result of commutative algebra frequently used to lift information from the fiber of a sheaf over a point (as for example a coherent sheaf over a scheme) to give information on the stalk at that point".

I began writing the article after getting some glimmers of what it was really about (in the minds of people who really use the stuff) from this MathOverflow thread, I think especially the answer by Roy Smith. I especially like the application to the algebraic geometry form of the inverse function theorem.

James Deikun said:

The ideal does have to be finitely generated to apply Nakayama's Lemma, indeed.

Yes, I meant to say "finitely generated ideal".

Here's a nice counterexample when your ideal is not finitely generated. Let RRR be the ring of continuous complex-valued functions on [0,1][0,1][0,1] and let III be the ideal consisting of functions that vanish at 000. Then I2=II^2 = II2=I but III is not of the form pRp RpR for any idempotent p∈Rp \in Rp∈R (which would need to be a continuous function that only takes the values 000 and/or 111).

Todd Trimble said:

Nakayama's lemma seems to be like Yoneda's lemma, being one of these simple results that people in the know use all the time and is coincidentally named after a Japanese mathematician.

I was thinking about that. But what I'd really like to do is derive Nakayama's lemma from the Yoneda lemma! Then I could annoy people by saying "Nakayama's lemma? That's just a corollary of the Yoneda lemma."

Now, it may be hopeless to derive the Nakayama lemma from the Yoneda lemma. But the Nakayama lemma does follow from ideas connected to the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, and that theorem has a vaguely Yoneda-ish feel, at least in my fevered brain.

Remember, it says that if you take a square matrix AAA and define its characteristic polynomial ppp by

p(λ)=det(λI−A)p(\lambda) = \mathrm{det}(\lambda I - A)p(λ)=det(λI−A)

then you get

p(A)=0 p(A) = 0p(A)=0
There's some sort of weird self-reference here, like "AAA is the walking root of its own characteristic polynomial".
And that "walking" business feels vaguely Yoneda-esque (to my fevered brain).

Here's a fake one-line proof of the Cayley-Hamilton theorem:

p(A)=det(AI−A)=0p(A) = \mathrm{det}(A I - A) = 0p(A)=det(AI−A)=0

Puzzle for beginners: spot why this proof is fake.

Puzzle for experts: try to morph it into a real proof!

John Baez said:

Puzzle for beginners: spot why this proof is fake.

Puzzle for experts: try to morph it into a real proof!

The matrices of endomorphisms approach

I'd be glad to see (or better find) a proof which use modern tools, ie. that I could understand easily (in my head, the more there is structure and the less there are tricks, the easier it is to understand). A modern definition of the determinant is like this:

  • For every kkk-vector space EEE of dimension nnn, and for every 1≤k≤n1 \le k \le n1≤k≤n, there is the kthk^{th}kth exterior power Λk(E)\Lambda^k(E)Λk(E) of EEE which is the quotient of the kthk^{th}kth tensor power E⊗kE^{\otimes k}E⊗k by the equalities vσ(1)⊗...⊗vσ(k)=ϵ(σ).v1⊗...⊗vkv_{\sigma(1)} \otimes ... \otimes v_{\sigma(k)} = \epsilon(\sigma).v_{1} \otimes ... \otimes v_{k}vσ(1)​⊗...⊗vσ(k)​=ϵ(σ).v1​⊗...⊗vk​ for every permutation σ∈Sk\sigma \in \mathfrak{S}_{k}σ∈Sk​ and where ϵ(σ)\epsilon(\sigma)ϵ(σ) is the signature of σ\sigmaσ (the next exterior powers are not very interesting because they are equal to 000)

  • If (e1,...,en)(e_{1},...,e_{n})(e1​,...,en​) is a basis of EEE, then the ei1∧...∧eike_{i_{1}} \wedge ... \wedge e_{i_{k}}ei1​​∧...∧eik​​ where 1≤i1<...<ik≤n1 \le i_{1} < ... < i_{k} \le n1≤i1​<...<ik​≤n form a basis of Λk(E)\Lambda^k(E)Λk(E). It follows that dim(Λk(E))=(nk)dim(\Lambda^k(E))=\binom{n}{k}dim(Λk(E))=(kn​). In particular (e1∧...∧en)(e_{1} \wedge ... \wedge e_{n})(e1​∧...∧en​) is a basis of Λn(E)\Lambda^n(E)Λn(E) which is then of dimension 111.

  • As for tensor powers, you can take the exterior power of a map. If u:E→Eu:E \rightarrow Eu:E→E is an endomorphism, then Λn(u):Λn(V)→Λn(V)\Lambda^n(u):\Lambda^n(V) \rightarrow \Lambda^n(V)Λn(u):Λn(V)→Λn(V) sends e1∧...∧ene_{1}\wedge ... \wedge e_{n}e1​∧...∧en​ to λ.e1∧...∧en\lambda.e_{1}\wedge ... \wedge e_{n}λ.e1​∧...∧en​ for a unique λ∈k\lambda \in kλ∈k.

The definition of det(u)det(u)det(u) is then:

  • det(u)det(u)det(u) is the unique scalar such that Λn(u)=det(u).1Λn(E)\Lambda^n(u)=det(u).1_{\Lambda^n(E)}Λn(u)=det(u).1Λn(E)​ ie. such that Λn(u)(e1∧...∧en)=det(u).e1∧...∧en\Lambda^n(u)(e_1 \wedge ... \wedge e_n)=det(u).e_{1} \wedge ... \wedge e_nΛn(u)(e1​∧...∧en​)=det(u).e1​∧...∧en​

By definition, the characteristic polynomial p(u)p(u)p(u) of uuu is then given by:

  • p(u)(λ)p(u)(\lambda)p(u)(λ) is the unique scalar such that Λn(λ.1E−u)=p(u).1Λn(E)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)=p(u).1_{\Lambda^n(E)}Λn(λ.1E​−u)=p(u).1Λn(E)​
Let's verify that p(u)p(u)p(u) is really a polynomial (map) first.

Λn(λ.1E−u)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)Λn(λ.1E​−u) is the map from Λn(E)\Lambda^n(E)Λn(E) to Λn(E)\Lambda^n(E)Λn(E) which acts like this on the basis

(1)(1)\quad(1) e1∧...∧en↦e_{1}\wedge ... \wedge e_n \mapstoe1​∧...∧en​↦
(λ.1E−u)(e1)∧...∧(λ.1E−u)(en)=(λ.e1−u(e1))∧...∧(λ.en−u(en))(\lambda.1_E-u)(e_1)\wedge ... \wedge (\lambda.1_E-u)(e_n) = (\lambda.e_1-u(e_1)) \wedge ... \wedge (\lambda.e_n-u(e_n))(λ.1E​−u)(e1​)∧...∧(λ.1E​−u)(en​)=(λ.e1​−u(e1​))∧...∧(λ.en​−u(en​))

The matrix (ak,l)1≤k,l≤n(a_{k,l})_{1 \le k,l \le n}(ak,l​)1≤k,l≤n​ of uuu is defined by the equations
(2)u(ek)=∑1≤l≤nak,l.el∀1≤k≤n(2)\quad u(e_k) = \underset{1 \le l \le n}{\sum}a_{k,l}.e_{l}\quad\forall 1 \le k \le n(2)u(ek​)=1≤l≤n∑​ak,l​.el​∀1≤k≤n
Let me use (2)(2)(2) into (1)(1)(1). Now I get that Λn(λ.1E−u)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)Λn(λ.1E​−u) is the map from Λn(E)\Lambda^n(E)Λn(E) to Λn(E)\Lambda^n(E)Λn(E) which acts like this on the basis:

e1∧...∧en↦e_{1}\wedge ... \wedge e_n \mapstoe1​∧...∧en​↦
(λ.e1−∑1≤l≤na1,l.el)∧...∧(λ.en−∑1≤l≤nan,l.el)(\lambda.e_1-\underset{1 \le l \le n}{\sum}a_{1,l}.e_{l}) \wedge ... \wedge (\lambda.e_n-\underset{1 \le l \le n}{\sum}a_{n,l}.e_{l})(λ.e1​−1≤l≤n∑​a1,l​.el​)∧...∧(λ.en​−1≤l≤n∑​an,l​.el​)

ie. Λn(λ.1E−u)(e1∧...∧en)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)(e_1 \wedge ... \wedge e_n)Λn(λ.1E​−u)(e1​∧...∧en​)
=(λ.e1−∑1≤l≤na1,l.el)∧...∧(λ.en−∑1≤l≤nan,l.el)= (\lambda.e_1-\underset{1 \le l \le n}{\sum}a_{1,l}.e_{l}) \wedge ... \wedge (\lambda.e_n-\underset{1 \le l \le n}{\sum}a_{n,l}.e_{l})=(λ.e1​−1≤l≤n∑​a1,l​.el​)∧...∧(λ.en​−1≤l≤n∑​an,l​.el​)

=((λ−a1,1).e1−a1,2.e2−...−a1,nen)∧...∧(−an,1.e1−...−an,n−1en−1+(λ−an,n).en)= ((\lambda-a_{1,1}).e_1- a_{1,2}.e_{2}-...-a_{1,n}e_n) \wedge ... \wedge (-a_{n,1}.e_{1}-...-a_{n,n-1}e_{n-1}+(\lambda-a_{n,n}).e_n)=((λ−a1,1​).e1​−a1,2​.e2​−...−a1,n​en​)∧...∧(−an,1​.e1​−...−an,n−1​en−1​+(λ−an,n​).en​)
=∑1≤i1,...,in≤nci1,...,in.ei1∧...∧ein= \underset{1 \le i_1,...,i_n \le n}{\sum}c_{i_1,...,i_n}.e_{i_1}\wedge...\wedge e_{i_n}=1≤i1​,...,in​≤n∑​ci1​,...,in​​.ei1​​∧...∧ein​​
where ci1,...,inc_{i_1,...,i_n}ci1​,...,in​​ is a uniquely determined scalar.

(∗)(*)\quad(∗) Remember that vσ(1)∧...∧vσ(n)=ϵ(σ).v1∧...∧vnv_{\sigma(1)} \wedge ... \wedge v_{\sigma(n)} = \epsilon(\sigma).v_{1}\wedge...\wedge v_{n}vσ(1)​∧...∧vσ(n)​=ϵ(σ).v1​∧...∧vn​ which gives in particular that v1∧...∧vn=0v_{1} \wedge ... \wedge v_{n}=0v1​∧...∧vn​=0 when there is a couple 1≤i<j≤n1 \le i < j \le n1≤i<j≤n such that vi=vjv_{i}=v_{j}vi​=vj​.
For what it's worth, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem is proved in the nLab here, as a relatively easy consequence of Cramer's rule. By the way, Cayley-Hamilton holds over any commutative ring.
Yeah, thanks. I'm just trying to do my proof (I do the puzzle).

I prefer if there is no use of something like the Cramer's rule and if it follows from a direct computation by applying the definitions (that's probably a matter of taste). But I can't guarantee that it is not going to take me the whole day -- if it works.
So, I continue my computation.
Let me rewrite slightly differently what I wrote before (I deleted all the terms which are equal to 000 using (∗)(*)(∗) and enumerated the other ones using the symmetric group):

Λn(λ.1E−u)(e1∧...∧en)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)(e_1 \wedge ... \wedge e_n)Λn(λ.1E​−u)(e1​∧...∧en​)
=∑σ∈Sncσ(1),...,σ(n).eσ(1)∧...∧eσ(n)=\underset{\sigma \in \mathfrak{S_n}}{\sum}c_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}.e_{\sigma(1)}\wedge ... \wedge e_{\sigma(n)}=σ∈Sn​∑​cσ(1),...,σ(n)​.eσ(1)​∧...∧eσ(n)​

John Baez said:

Todd Trimble said:

Nakayama's lemma seems to be like Yoneda's lemma, being one of these simple results that people in the know use all the time and is coincidentally named after a Japanese mathematician.

I was thinking about that. But what I'd really like to do is derive Nakayama's lemma from the Yoneda lemma! Then I could annoy people by saying "Nakayama's lemma? That's just a corollary of the Yoneda lemma."

That's a fun motivation: finding a new way to annoy people using the Yoneda lemma. JK

I don't have a lot to say at the moment about a connection between the two, but it does remind me of stuff that Andre Scedrov said near the beginning of his AMS Memoir Forcing and Classifying Topoi. On page 11, he cites one of the standard approaches to proving the Cayley-Hamilton theorem as an example of universal thinking: "one always takes only the bare essentials needed to satisfy the hypothesis". So here, he says, "If ... PM(t)=det⁡(tI−M)P_M(t) = \det(tI - M)PM​(t)=det(tI−M), then showing PM(M)=0P_M(M) = 0PM​(M)=0 at once is too hard. Rather, think of tI−MtI - MtI−M as a matrix over k[t]k[t]k[t], EEE as a module over k[t]k[t]k[t], and show PM(t)E=0P_M(t)E = 0PM​(t)E=0 in this setting."

Where is he going with this? He's making an analogy with the process also described by Lawvere in his Variable Sets, Etendu, and Variable Structures in Topoi: just as one goes from a ring of constants kkk to k[t]k[t]k[t] by adjoining a variable, so one can move from "constant sets" to more "variable sets" (e.g., presheaf toposes), and then the forcing process (localizing with respect to forcing conditions) is analogous to taking a quotient modulo an ideal, tailor-made to fit the hypotheses one is after.

So there is the idea of using generic elements. In the Yoneda lemma, one considers an identity morphism as a "generic generalized element".

That's all I got at the moment... wish I had more.

Actually, I've never had a good understanding of this theorem and I didn't know exterior powers or even the tensor product when I learned it so I'm trying to see what I can do today using these tools (by the way I haven't used the hypothesis that the scalars are in a field, maybe the one that r+r≠0r+r\neq 0r+r=0 if r≠0r \neq 0r=0, not sure)

I use again (∗)(*)(∗) to get:
Λn(λ.1E−u)(e1∧...∧en)\Lambda^{n}(\lambda.1_E-u)(e_1 \wedge ... \wedge e_n)Λn(λ.1E​−u)(e1​∧...∧en​)
=∑σ∈Snϵ(σ).cσ(1),...,σ(n).e1∧...∧en=\underset{\sigma \in \mathfrak{S_n}}{\sum}\epsilon(\sigma).c_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}.e_{1}\wedge ... \wedge e_{n}=σ∈Sn​∑​ϵ(σ).cσ(1),...,σ(n)​.e1​∧...∧en​

So, we have:
(3)p(u)(λ)=∑σ∈Snϵ(σ).cσ(1),...,σ(n)(3) \quad p(u)(\lambda)=\underset{\sigma \in \mathfrak{S_n}}{\sum}\epsilon(\sigma).c_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}(3)p(u)(λ)=σ∈Sn​∑​ϵ(σ).cσ(1),...,σ(n)​
The ci1,...,inc_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}ci1​,...,in​​ are polynomials in λ\lambdaλ (of degree ≤n\le n≤n), which depend on the matrix of uuu, although I don't want to write down the expression explicitely...
So p(u)(λ)p(u)(\lambda)p(u)(λ) is really a polynomial (of degree nnn) in λ\lambdaλ.
Now, we want to prove that p(u)(u)=0p(u)(u)=0p(u)(u)=0
Well, I can't make any further progress if I don't work on the coefficients cσ(1),...,σ(n)c_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}cσ(1),...,σ(n)​

I can decompose
(4)cσ(1),...,σ(n)=d1σ...dnσ(4) \quad c_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}=d^{\sigma}_1...d^{\sigma}_n(4)cσ(1),...,σ(n)​=d1σ​...dnσ​

=((λ−a1,1).e1−a1,2.e2−...−a1,nen)∧...∧(−an,1.e1−...−an,n−1en−1+(λ−an,n).en)= ((\lambda-a_{1,1}).e_1- a_{1,2}.e_{2}-...-a_{1,n}e_n) \wedge ... \wedge (-a_{n,1}.e_{1}-...-a_{n,n-1}e_{n-1}+(\lambda-a_{n,n}).e_n)=((λ−a1,1​).e1​−a1,2​.e2​−...−a1,n​en​)∧...∧(−an,1​.e1​−...−an,n−1​en−1​+(λ−an,n​).en​)

I'm gonna try to compute some coefficients here to get an idea
The coeff before e1∧...∧ene_{1}\wedge...\wedge e_ne1​∧...∧en​ is (λ−a1,1)(λ−a2,2)...(λ−an,n)(\lambda-a_{1,1})(\lambda-a_{2,2})...(\lambda-a_{n,n})(λ−a1,1​)(λ−a2,2​)...(λ−an,n​)
The coeff before e1∧e3∧e2e_{1} \wedge e_{3} \wedge e_{2}e1​∧e3​∧e2​ (if we had n=3n=3n=3) would be (λ−a1,1)(−a2,3)(−a3,2)(\lambda-a_{1,1})(-a_{2,3})(-a_{3,2})(λ−a1,1​)(−a2,3​)(−a3,2​)
The coeff before e3∧e2∧e1e_{3}\wedge e_{2} \wedge e_{1}e3​∧e2​∧e1​ would be (−a1,3)(λ−a2,2)(−a3,1)(-a_{1,3})(\lambda-a_{2,2})(-a_{3,1})(−a1,3​)(λ−a2,2​)(−a3,1​)
So, there is a pattern

The coeff before eσ(1)∧...∧eσ(n)e_{\sigma(1)} \wedge ...\wedge e_{\sigma(n)}eσ(1)​∧...∧eσ(n)​ is my cσ(1),...,σ(n)=d1σ...dnσc_{\sigma(1),...,\sigma(n)}=d_{1}^{\sigma}...d_{n}^{\sigma}cσ(1),...,σ(n)​=d1σ​...dnσ​ where for every 1≤i≤n1 \le i \le n1≤i≤n:
(5a)diσ=(−ai,σ(i))(5a)\quad d_{i}^{\sigma}=(-a_{i,\sigma(i)})(5a)diσ​=(−ai,σ(i)​) if i≠σ(i)i \neq \sigma(i)i=σ(i)
(5b)diσ=(λ−ai,σ(i))(5b) \quad d_{i}^{\sigma}=(\lambda-a_{i,\sigma(i)})(5b)diσ​=(λ−ai,σ(i)​) if i=σ(i)i = \sigma(i)i=σ(i)
Let's combine (3),(4),(5)(3),(4),(5)(3),(4),(5):

(6)p(u)(λ)=∑σ∈Snϵ(σ)∏1≤i≤n, i≠σ(i)(−ai,σ(i))∏1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)(λ−ai,σ(i))(6) \quad p(u)(\lambda) = \underset{\sigma \in \mathfrak{S}_n}{\sum}\epsilon(\sigma)\underset{1 \le i \le n, ~i \neq \sigma(i)}{\prod}(-a_{i,\sigma(i)}) \underset{1 \le i \le n,~ i = \sigma(i)}{\prod}(\lambda-a_{i,\sigma(i)})(6)p(u)(λ)=σ∈Sn​∑​ϵ(σ)1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)∏​(−ai,σ(i)​)1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)∏​(λ−ai,σ(i)​)
Now, it's very clear that p(u)(λ)p(u)(\lambda)p(u)(λ) is a polynomial!

We thus want to prove that:
(7)∑σ∈Snϵ(σ)∏1≤i≤n, i≠σ(i)(−ai,σ(i))∏1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)(u−ai,σ(i).1E)=0(7)\quad \underset{\sigma \in \mathfrak{S}_n}{\sum}\epsilon(\sigma)\underset{1 \le i \le n, ~i \neq \sigma(i)}{\prod}(-a_{i,\sigma(i)}) \underset{1 \le i \le n,~ i = \sigma(i)}{\prod}(u-a_{i,\sigma(i)}.1_E)=0(7)σ∈Sn​∑​ϵ(σ)1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)∏​(−ai,σ(i)​)1≤i≤n, i=σ(i)∏​(u−ai,σ(i)​.1E​)=0
Be aware that the second product must be interpreted as a composite...
Let's note (e1∗,...,en∗)(e_{1}^*,...,e_{n}^*)(e1∗​,...,en∗​) the dual basis of (e1,...,en)(e_1,...,e_n)(e1​,...,en​)
I'm going to use the natural isomorphism End(E)≅E⊗E∗End(E) \cong E \otimes E^*End(E)≅E⊗E∗
which sends an endomorphism vvv to ∑1≤k,l≤nel∗(v(ek)).el⊗ek∗\underset{1 \le k,l \le n}{\sum}e_l^*(v(e_k)).e_{l}\otimes e_k^*1≤k,l≤n∑​el∗​(v(ek​)).el​⊗ek∗​
(Note that el∗(v(ek)))e_{l}^*(v(e_k)))el∗​(v(ek​))) is just the coefficients (k,l)(k,l)(k,l) in the matrix of vvv)
In fact it is also an isomorphism of kkk-algebras
The product in E⊗E∗E \otimes E^*E⊗E∗ is given by (v⊗ϕ)⊗(w⊗ψ)↦ϕ(w).v⊗ψ(v \otimes \phi) \otimes (w \otimes \psi) \mapsto \phi(w).v \otimes \psi(v⊗ϕ)⊗(w⊗ψ)↦ϕ(w).v⊗ψ

(The idea is that ψ\psiψ absorbs the initial entry, www is an intermediate output, ϕ\phiϕ absorbs this intermediate output, and then vvv is a final output, that's why you get the coefficient ϕ(w)\phi(w)ϕ(w))

I'm going to rewrite the LHS of (7)(7)(7) as the nnn-ary product applied to an element of (E⊗E∗)⊗n(E \otimes E^*)^{\otimes n}(E⊗E∗)⊗n ie. I will explicit an element y∈(E⊗E∗)⊗ny \in (E \otimes E^*)^{\otimes n}y∈(E⊗E∗)⊗n such that if we consider the nnn-ary product ∇n:(E⊗E∗)⊗n→(E⊗E∗)\nabla^n:(E \otimes E^*)^{\otimes n} \rightarrow (E \otimes E^*)∇n:(E⊗E∗)⊗n→(E⊗E∗), then the LHS of (7)(7)(7) is equal to ∇n(y)\nabla^n(y)∇n(y)
I do that because it feels too hard to compute the composite/product directly
but it will still replace uuu by coefficients of its matrix + basis and dual basis elements in this LHS, so it should be better

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I prefer if there is no use of something like the Cramer's rule and if it follows from a direct computation by applying the definitions (that's probably a matter of taste). But I can't guarantee that it is not going to take me the whole day -- if it works.

With regard to Cramer's rule: it's an easy consequence of the fact that the determinant is an alternating multilinear map Vn=V×…×V→kV^n = V \times \ldots \times V \to kVn=V×…×V→k. In other words, a direct computation by applying the definition of determinant.

But the only reason for mentioning it is that it leads directly to the adjugate matrix of a matrix AAA, viz. a matrix A~\widetilde{A}A such that AA~=A~A=det⁡(A)⋅IA \widetilde{A} = \widetilde{A} A = \det(A) \cdot IAA=AA=det(A)⋅I. The presence of such a matrix A~\widetilde{A}A is the key thing used in the nLab to prove Cayley-Hamilton, which has a nice short conceptual proof (essentially the same proof as in Lang's Algebra, if I remember correctly).
It looks more intelligent. I'm still intrigued to know if my brute-force calculation can finish

I'm all for experimentation, but I think it would be better to work these things out by yourself and not go through a long public calculation. I think the main problem may be that not many people here would be willing to read through all of it, and besides, people were beginning to have a conversation about Nakayama's lemma.

James Deikun said:

Is there any good proof that doesn't make use of adjugates?

There's a kind of "dirty" proof where one sees that diagonal matrices DDD solve the characteristic polynomial equation (since p(D)p(D)p(D) for a polynomial ppp is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are p(di)p(d_i)p(di​), where did_idi​ are the entries for DDD). Since the determinant is invariant under conjugation, we can then extend Cayley-Hamilton to the set of all diagonalizable matrices. Then, since diagonalizable matrices are dense in the set of all matrices, and since the set of matrices that satisfy CH is a closed set (even in the Zariski topology), the Cayley-Hamilton holds for all matrices.

One has to think a bit carefully though how well this holds up for all commutative rings. I'm not sure that density assertion does.

Ack, diagonalizable matrices are not dense of course. I guess I had in mind the classical case where the commutative ring is a field, and apply the idea that the statement of CH is insensitive to whether we stick with that field or pass to an extension field, and use this to pass to an algebraic closure and argue there. So, yeah, it's looking dirtier by the moment.

I consider free modules of finite rank over a given ring RRR.

Fix a rank 1 free module AAA (not necessarily with a given choice of isomorphism with RRR) and let (−)∗(-) ^\ast(−)∗ abbreviate the functor Hom(−,A)Hom(-, A)Hom(−,A).
A perfect pairing V⊗W→AV\otimes W\to AV⊗W→A is a map such that both ways of currying give isomorphisms, so V≅W∗V\cong W^\astV≅W∗ and W≅V∗W\cong V^\astW≅V∗.
For any perfect pairing σ:V≅W∗\sigma:V\cong W^\astσ:V≅W∗, and for TTT an endomorphism of VVV, construct a map

(σTσ−1)∗:W∗∗→W∗∗(\sigma T\sigma^{-1})^{\ast} :W^{\ast\ast} \to W^{\ast\ast}(σTσ−1)∗:W∗∗→W∗∗
and by virtue of the natural isomorphism W≅W∗∗W\cong W^{\ast\ast}W≅W∗∗ i can regard this as a map T♯:W→WT^\sharp:W\to WT♯:W→W.

This map is called the adjoint of TTT and is uniquely defined by ⟨Tv,w⟩=⟨v,T♯w⟩\left\langle Tv, w\right\rangle=\left\langle v, T^\sharp w\right\rangle ⟨Tv,w⟩=⟨v,T♯w⟩. Similarly if FFF is an endomorphism of WWW its adjoint is an endomorphism of VVV.

Now take VVV to be a free module of rank nnn, let W=Λn−1(M)W=\Lambda^{n-1}(M)W=Λn−1(M)
and take AAA to be Λn(M)\Lambda^{n}(M)Λn(M). The wedge product is a perfect pairing.

If TTT is any endomorphism of VVV then because the exterior algebra is a functor F=Λn−1(T)F=\Lambda^{n-1}(T)F=Λn−1(T) is an endomorphism of W=Λn−1(V)W=\Lambda^{n-1}(V)W=Λn−1(V). So it has an adjoint R=F♯R=F^\sharpR=F♯ which is an endomorphism of TTT. I call this endomorphism the adjugate of TTT.

Its defining property is that it satisfies
R(v)∧v2∧⋯∧vn=v∧T(v2)∧⋯∧T(vn)R(v) \land v_2\land \dots\land v_n=v\land T(v_2)\land\dots\land T(v_n)R(v)∧v2​∧⋯∧vn​=v∧T(v2​)∧⋯∧T(vn​).

For any basis of VVV there are standard bases for WWW and AAA. Moreover as soon as a basis is fixed VVV is isomorphic to its dual space and so are WWW and AAA. I can describe the computation of the matrices arising from these but it will be a bit tedious, i will leave it as an exercise

it's helpful here to know that if TTT is an endomorphism of VVV then its determinant can be defined as the unique scalar rrr in RRR such that Λn(T)\Lambda^n(T)Λn(T) is equal to r⋅−r\cdot - r⋅− as endomorphisms of Λn(V)\Lambda^n(V)Λn(V).
that's why the adjugate is closely connected to the determinant.

From this perspective is there a way to make the adjugate still work for modules that are not free? Apparently the Cayley-Hamilton theorem itself still works in this situation, just as long as the ring is commutative.
(This is much nicer than picking a basis and manipulating a bunch of formulas though.)

i don't know of a reformulation of the proof where you get it for free but it's a corollary. If MMM is fg take a surjection ϕ:Rn→M\phi:R^n\to Mϕ:Rn→M, then T:M→MT:M\to MT:M→M lifts to T′:Rn→RnT':R^n\to R^nT′:Rn→Rn such that the square commutes. then you apply the theorem to T′T'T′ and use this to get it for TTT

Todd Trimble said:

There's a kind of "dirty" proof where one sees that diagonal matrices DDD solve the characteristic polynomial equation (since p(D)p(D)p(D) for a polynomial ppp is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are p(di)p(d_i)p(di​), where did_idi​ are the entries for DDD). Since the determinant is invariant under conjugation, we can then extend Cayley-Hamilton to the set of all diagonalizable matrices. Then, since diagonalizable matrices are dense in the set of all matrices, and since the set of matrices that satisfy CH is a closed set (even in the Zariski topology), the Cayley-Hamilton holds for all matrices.

I kind of like dirty arguments where you prove something on a dense set and then use continuity to handle the rest. Maybe it's my background in analysis: these arguments come very naturally to me. For example, that's one of my favorite proofs of

exp⁡(tr(A))=det⁡(exp⁡(A)) \exp(\mathrm{tr}(A)) = \det(\exp(A)) exp(tr(A))=det(exp(A))

But you know this better than anyone, Todd - in our recent work I've been reaching for Zariski density arguments like a drunk reaches for his bottle. :upside_down:

I do however agree that there's something unsatisfying about proving an equation between algebraic functions by proving it at just enough points to let a density argument do the rest: in doing so one may be missing the deeper insights required to prove it more directly.

Todd Trimble said:

Ack, diagonalizable matrices are not dense of course. I guess I had in mind the classical case where the commutative ring is a field, and apply the idea that the statement of CH is insensitive to whether we stick with that field or pass to an extension field, and use this to pass to an algebraic closure and argue there. So, yeah, it's looking dirtier by the moment.

I'm wondering if there is an analogue of Smith normal form/Jordan canonical form for say PID entries (not like SNF, where you can pick different bases on either side, though), and then prove Cayley–Hamilton for that special form.

Or even just the pedestrian step of reducing to the case from a block diagonal matrix to the blocks separately, and then thinking about what happens with a single Jordan block, say (or the analogue not over a field).

Obviously when working over a more general commutative ring you almost surely have problems in finding invariant submodules and more options for what submodules can be. Checking now, I see that "hereditary" rings are those where submodules of free modules are projective, so things can get pretty weird, and this is probably not a path all the way to a general proof.

In general I don't find any of the proofs of Cayley-Hamilton very conceptual, and none of them seem to prove it in the full generality where it holds. In particular, any proof based on the adjugate doesn't seem like it would work for the case of quaternionic or split-quaternionic matrices. (How do you actually define determinant of quaternionic matrices anyway, BTW?)

Does Cayley-Hamilton even hold for quaternionic matrices?

I don't think there's a quaternion-valued determinant of quaternionic matrices obeying det(gh) = det(g) det(h). (It would take more conditions to turn this thought into a theorem.)

The good determinants for quaternionic matrices are the Dieudonne determinant and the Study determinant, which works out to be the square of the Dieudonne determinant. I wrote a bunch about these for the nLab.
The Dieudonne determinant is an idea that works for matrices valued in any division ring.

According to https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0024379595005439 it's a little more complicated than the paradigm case; the "characteristic polynomial" here detects right eigenvalues (Ax=xλAx = x\lambdaAx=xλ) and is obtained by intervening in the process of obtaining the Study determinant by doing the Iλ−AI\lambda - AIλ−A manipulation just before taking the complex determinant. It is a polynomial of degree 2n2n2n with real coefficients, and its complex roots come in conjugate pairs, even the real ones, corresponding to nnn "conjugate 3-spheres" of right eigenvalues, counting multiplicity. As a real polynomial, it is pretty clear how to evaluate it even on a quaternionic matrix and the evaluation on AAA turns out to be 0.
